All words purporting to give a joint authority to three or more city officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons unless it shall be otherwise expressly declared in the law giving the authority. (7) Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision requires the head of a department or other officer of the city to do some act or perform some duty, it shall be construed to authorize such department head or officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to do the required act or perform the required duty unless the terms of the provision designate otherwise. (8) 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 33/321 Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done as provided in any code provision or ordinance or in any order issued pursuant to any ordinance, when expressed in days, shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last, except that if the last day is a Saturday, Sunday or a legal holiday it shall be excluded. When any such time is expressed in hours, the whole of Sunday, from midnight to midnight, shall be excluded. When the period of time prescribed is less than seven days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. (9) Shall, will, and may. The words "shall" and "will" are mandatory and not merely directory. The word "may" is permissive. (10) Conjunctions. Where a provision involves two or more items, conditions, provisions or events connected by the conjunction "and," "or" or "either … or," the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows, provided in appropriate cases the terms "and" and "or" are interchangeable: a. The term "and" indicates that all the connected items, conditions, provisions or events shall apply. b. The term "or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or events may apply singly or in any combination. c. The term "either … or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or events shall apply singly, but not in combination. (11) Statutory references. The abbreviation "O.C.G.A." means the "Official Code of Georgia Annotated" as now or hereafter amended. Any reference to a state act, whether by short title or year, page number and/or act number, is a reference to such act, as amended. Sec. 1-3. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this Code, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Advice and consent. Whenever the term "advice and consent" of the city council is used in this Code it shall be construed to mean an affirmative vote of the majority of the entire city council. City. The term "the city" or "this city" means the City of Ty Ty, Georgia. City council, council. The term "city council" or "council" means the City Council of the City of Ty Ty, Georgia. City hall. The term "city hall" means the City Hall of the City of Ty, Ty, Georgia. Code. The term "Code" means The Code of the City of Ty Ty, Georgia, as designated in section 1-1. County. The term "the county" or "this county" means Tift County, Georgia. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 34/321 Court. The term "court" means the municipal court of the city. Day. The term "day" means a calendar day of 24 hours. Governing authority, governing body. The term "governing authority" or "governing body" means the Mayor and City Council of the City of Ty Ty, Georgia. Judge or recorder. The term "judge" or "recorder" means the judge of the municipal court of the city. Mayor. The term "mayor" means the Mayor of the City of Ty Ty, Georgia. Mayor and city council. The term "mayor and city council" means the Mayor and City Council of the City of Ty Ty, Georgia. Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. Municipality. The term "municipality" is synonymous with the term "city" or "municipal corporation." Oath. The term "oath" includes an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the terms "affirm" and "affirmed" shall be equivalent to the terms "swear" and "sworn." Ordinance. The term "ordinance" means a legislative act of a general and permanent nature of the municipal governing body. Owner. The term "owner," when applied to a building or to land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or a part of such building or land. Person. The term "person" includes a corporation, firm, agency, partnership, association, organization, government, and any other group acting as a unit, as well as an individual. Personal property. The term "personal property" includes every species of property except real property, as hereinafter defined. Preceding, following. The terms "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. Property. The term "property" includes real, personal, and mixed estates and interests. Public place. The term "public place" means any park, cemetery, shopping center, schoolyard, or open space adjacent thereto, or any area available and accessible to the public, regardless of whether privately or publicly owned, and any place to which the public is invited or permitted to go or to congregate. Real property. The term "real property" includes lands, tenements, and hereditaments. Reasonable time or notice. The term "reasonable time or notice" means only such time as may be necessary for the prompt performance of the act required. Resolution. The term "resolution" means a legislative act of the municipal governing body of a special or temporary character. Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, but shall not include any unimproved areas between the curbline and improved walkways. Signature, subscription. The term "signature" or "subscription" includes a mark intended as such when the person cannot write. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 35/321 State. The term "state" or "this state" means the State of Georgia. Street. The term "street" means any public way, road, highway, street, avenue, boulevard, parkway, alley, viaduct or bridge, and the approach thereto, within the city. Tenant or occupant. The term "tenant" or "occupant," when applied to a building or land, includes any person holding a written or oral lease of, or who occupies the whole or a part of, such building or land, either alone or with others. Week. The term "week" means seven calendar days. Writing or written. The terms "writing" and "written" include printing and any other mode of representing words and letters. Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. Sec. 1-4. - Catchlines of sections, effect of history notes. (a) The catchlines of the several sections and subsections of this Code are intended as mere captions to indicate the contents of the section or subsection and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section or subsection, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections or subsections, including the headings and catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (b) The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect and are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. Editor's notes and state law references which appear after sections of this Code or which otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the user and have no legal effect. Sec. 1-5. - Effect of repeal or expiration of Code section or ordinance. (a) The repeal of a Code section or ordinance, or its expiration by virtue of any provision contained therein, shall not affect any right accrued or any offense committed, any penalty or punishment incurred, or any proceeding commenced before the repeal took effect or the ordinance expired. (b) When any ordinance repealing a former Code section, ordinance, clause or provision shall be itself repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive such former Code section, ordinance, clause, or provision, unless it shall be expressly so provided. Sec. 1-6. - Amending Code. (a) All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code shall be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein. In the case of repealed chapters, sections, and subsections or any part thereof by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances, as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 36/321 ordinances until such time as the Code and subsequent ordinances omitted are readopted as a new Code by the city council. (b) Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "Section ____________ of The Code of the City of Ty Ty, Georgia, is hereby amended to read as follows:…." The new provisions may then be set out in full as desired. (c) In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "The Code of the City of Ty Ty, Georgia, is hereby amended by adding a section (or chapter, article, division or subdivision, as appropriate) to be numbered ____________, that reads as follows:…." The new provision shall then be set out in full as desired. (d) All sections, chapters, or provisions sought to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, with reference to the subject matter, as the case may be. Sec. 1-7. - Altering Code. It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby, except by ordinance or resolution or other official act of the mayor and city council. Sec. 1-8. - General penalty. (a) In this section, the term "violation of this Code" means: (1) Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful, an offense or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance; (2) Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance; or (3) Failure to perform an act if the failure is declared a misdemeanor or an offense or unlawful by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. (b) In this section, the term "violation of this Code" does not include the failure of a city officer or city employee to perform an official duty, unless it is provided that failure to perform the duty is to be punished as provided in this section or it is clear from the context that it is the intent to impose the penalty provided for in this section upon the officer or employee. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 37/321 (c) Except as otherwise provided: (1) A person convicted of a violation of this Code shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00, imprisonment for a term not exceeding six months, or compulsory labor for the city on the streets, sidewalks, squares, or other public places for a period not exceeding 30 days, or any combination thereof. (2) With respect to violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time, each day the violation continues is a separate offense. (3) With respect to violations of this Code that are not continuous with respect to time, each day the violation continues is a separate offense. (d) The imposition of a penalty does not prevent revocation or suspension of a license, permit or franchise or other administrative sanctions. (e) Violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time are a public nuisance and may be abated by injunctive or other equitable relief and by such other means as are provided by law. The imposition of a penalty does not prevent equitable relief. State law reference— Limits on general penalty, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2); authority to punish ordinance violations by requiring labor, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-8. Sec. 1-9. - Severability. If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or other portion of this Code is, for any reason, declared invalid, in whole or in part, by any court, agency, commission, legislative body or other authority of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent portion. Such declaration shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof, which other portions shall continue in full force and effect, unless the portion declared invalid would clearly and unequivocally cause the remainder of the ordinance to have a meaning contrary to its original meaning before a portion of the ordinance was declared invalid. Any portion that is declared invalid will be stricken from the ordinance; and the remaining portion of the ordinance shall continue and remain valid and enforceable unless the ordinance as it remains would clearly be contrary to the intent of the council when it was enacted. Sec. 1-10. - Supplementation of Code. (a) By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code should be prepared at least on an annual basis. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive, permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council during the period covered by the supplement, and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 38/321 have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. (b) In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. (c) When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier, meaning the person authorized to prepare the supplement, may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: (1) Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions. (2) Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles. (3) Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers. (4) Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ to ____________," inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code. (5) Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code, but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. Sec. 1-11. - Rates, charges, or fees established. (a) Unless otherwise provided for, all rates, charges, or fees necessary for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this Code shall be as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution or ordinance of the city council from time to time. Any rates, charges, or fees established by the city pursuant to the regulations or requirements established herein may be changed from time to time by the city council, and such changes shall both be considered an amendment to this Code. (b) Whenever any provision of this Code provides that a rate, charge, or fee shall be established by the city council from time to time, and the amount of such rate, charge, or fee is not expressed in this Code in any dollar amount, 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 39/321 then the amount of such rate, charge, or fee shall be the most recent and latest amount established, set or fixed by the city council by ordinance, resolution or motion. Sec. 1-12. - Ordinances not affected by Code. (a) Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: (1) Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code; (2) Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness; (3) Any contract or obligation assumed by the city; (4) Any ordinance or resolution fixing the salary of any city officer or employee, unless superseded; (5) Any ordinance or resolution establishing and prescribing employment and personnel policies and procedures and providing employee benefits; (6) Any right of franchise granted by the city to any person, firm, or corporation; (7) Any ordinance or resolution dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, closing, opening, widening, paving, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city; (8) Any ordinance or resolution establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the city; (9) Any appropriation ordinance; (10) Any ordinance or resolution which, by its own terms, is effective for a stated or limited term; (11) Any ordinance or resolution providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor; 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 40/321 (12) Any zoning ordinance or amendments thereto, and any ordinance establishing a board of zoning appeals or planning commission, including joint commissions; (13) Any ordinance or resolution dedicating or accepting any subdivision plat or providing for subdivision regulations; (14) Any ordinance or resolution describing or altering the boundaries of the city or annexing property to the city; (15) The administrative ordinances or resolutions of the city not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this Code; (16) Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes not included in this Code; (17) Any ordinance or regulation prescribing traffic regulations for specific locations concerning through streets, parking limitations, parking prohibitions, one-way traffic, limitations on loads of vehicles or loading zones, not in conflict or inconsistent with this Code; (18) Any ordinance or resolution prohibiting the sale of alcoholic beverages within the city; (19) Any ordinance or resolution of agreement with another political subdivision; (20) Any ordinance assessing a fee, rate, charge or fine, unless superseded; and (21) Any other ordinance or resolution, or part thereof, which is not of a general and permanent nature, or which is referred to elsewhere in this Code as continuing in effect. (b) Nor shall the repeal of any such ordinance or resolution be construed to revive any ordinance, resolution or part thereof that has been repealed or superseded by a subsequent ordinance or resolution which is repealed or superseded by this chapter. All such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code.

div.head: Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION
div.p: ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 41/321 Secs. 2-1—2-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - DISCLAIMER OF LIABILITY FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authorization for purchase of insurance covering injuries resulting from governmental ownership and use of motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 33-24-51. Sec. 2-19. - Title. These regulations and restrictions shall be known and may be cited as the City of Ty Ty, Georgia "Liability for Injuries and Damages Ordinance." (Ord. No. 1997-2, § 1, 5-5-1997) Sec. 2-20. - Jurisdiction. These regulations and restrictions shall govern any injuries and/or damages to any person or property caused by the City of Ty Ty, its employees, agents, or property. (Ord. No. 1997-2, § 2, 5-5-1997) Sec. 2-21. - Purpose. These regulations and restrictions on the liability of the City of Ty Ty are imposed and designed to limit the liability of the City of Ty Ty and to protect public funds held by the City of Ty Ty from paying for the private claims of any party who contends that they were injured or damaged by the actions or failure to act by the City of Ty Ty. (Ord. No. 1997-2, § 3, 5-5-1997) Sec. 2-22. - Regulations and restrictions. Except to the extent provided by federal or state law, the city shall not be liable to any person or entity for any injuries, damages, claims, costs, or expenses caused by the city, its property, its employees, or its agents concerning any actions or failure to act by anyone connected with the city except as is otherwise set out in this article. It is the intention of this article that except where limited herein the city will claim its right to sovereign immunity so as to prevent it from being held responsible for any claims for injuries or damages alleged to be caused by the negligence or tortuous conduct of the city. The following regulations and restrictions shall apply and control: (1) The city council may at its discretion hear any complaint by any citizen for reimbursement of any damages or injuries for which they feel the city is responsible. To the extent that the city actually pays to such citizen a certain sum of money, then the sovereign immunity of the city shall be waived as to the amount actually paid and only to that amount. Any payment received by a citizen shall be payment in full satisfaction of any and all such claims against the city. (2) The city will not consider reimbursing any person for any damages or injuries unless the city council considers the matter and pays for the damages prior to any repairs being completed. This provision may be waived by the 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 42/321 city council only in the event that emergency repairs are required to prevent any further damages to such person's property. (3) The city shall not be liable to any citizen for any water or sewer damage that is done to the property of any person located in the city and caused by the water or sewer system of the city. (4) The city shall not be required under any circumstances to go onto the private property of any person located in the city to make any type of repairs, including but not limited to the digging out of any ditches or debris caused by water drainage. (5) To the extent that the city has insurance to cover any loss, damages, or injuries sustained by any person, said person may proceed against the insurance company to obtain compensation for its injuries or damages. In no event, however, shall the city be required to pay any amount and sovereign immunity shall only be waived to the extent that any person may be entitled to receive benefits from said insurance company and only to the extent that said insurance company pays for such damages or injuries. Nothing contained herein shall require the city to keep or maintain any insurance. (6) Nothing contained herein shall prevent any citizen from making any claim against any independent contractor that damages a citizen's property who was hired by the city. (7) The city shall not be liable to any person who is injured while upon the property of the city regardless of the cause of such injury. (8) In the event that the city has insurance to cover a particular situation or in the event that a third party with whom the city contracts damages an individual citizen's property, then the city at the city council's discretion may elect to assist the citizen in trying to collect either from the insurance company or from said independent contractor. However, nothing herein shall require the city to take any such action. (Ord. No. 1997-2, § 4, 5-5-1997) Secs. 2-23—2-47. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - LEGISLATIVE BODY Sec. 2-48. - Ordinance defined. An ordinance is hereby defined as being any law, statute, or enactment passed by the city council of a general nature which would apply to or could affect a substantial number of citizens in the city. Provided, however, that any enactment by the city no matter how specific and no matter how limited in application which is entitled an ordinance and which is passed with the same formality of an ordinance shall also be considered an ordinance and shall be deemed a specific ordinance regardless of whether or not said ordinance is labeled a specific ordinance. (Ord. No. 95-1, § G, 5-1-1995) Sec. 2-49. - Resolution defined. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 43/321 All other actions taken by the city council which are not ordinances shall be deemed resolutions of the city. Resolutions shall have the effect and force of laws and shall be binding on the city and its residents, invitees, and guests unless and until repealed by the city council. (Ord. No. 95-1, § H, 5-1-1995) Sec. 2-50. - Enactment of resolutions. Any resolution may be enacted by the city council upon such resolution being presented either in writing or verbally at any meeting of the city council, and said resolutions shall become effective immediately upon a majority of the councilmembers being present if a quorum exists voting in favor of said resolution. Provided, however, that the mayor of the city may veto any resolution within three days of the council meeting in which said resolution was passed if the mayor was actually present at said meeting. In the event that the mayor is not present at said meeting, then he may veto said legislation within three days after he receives written notice of the enactment or passage of said resolution. Provided, further, that if any two councilmembers or the mayor standing alone wish to bring any resolution up for another vote, they may do so either at the next regular meeting or at a special called meeting called for that purpose unless the city council has already taken actions which cannot be easily undone which would materially affect the city or any inhabitant of the city relying on such resolution. If upon a new vote the resolution is voted down, then the resolution shall be stricken from the record if the resolution has been in existence for a period of less than 40 days. Any resolution may be repealed by a majority vote of the city council if said resolution has been in existence for over 40 days. (Ord. No. 95-1, § I, 5-1-1995) Sec. 2-51. - Expenditures. Any expenditure by the city in the ordinary course of business shall be carried out by the city employees under other rules and regulations established by the council or the mayor. Any matters not in the ordinary course of business concerning expenditures of less than $7,500.00 shall be handled by a resolution of the city council. Any expenditure not in the ordinary course of business for a sum in excess of $7,500.00 shall be handled as an ordinance by the city. (Ord. No. 95-1, § J, 5-1-1995) Sec. 2-52. - Compensation for city councilmembers. Compensation for each member of city council and for the mayor of the city shall be established from time to time by the appropriate vote of the city council. (Ord. No. 95-7, § C, 9-11-1995) Sec. 2-53. - Title. The regulations in sections 2-53 through 2-56 shall be known and may be cited as the "Agenda for Council Meetings of the City of Ty Ty, Georgia." (Ord. No. 1997-4, § 1, 5-5-1997) Sec. 2-54. - Jurisdiction. Sections 2-53 through 2-56 shall govern the conduct of all city council meetings for the city. (Ord. No. 1997-4, § 2, 5-5-1997) Sec. 2-55. - Purpose. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 44/321 The regulations and restrictions in sections 2-53 through 2-56 are imposed and designed only for the smooth operation and orderly function of the meetings for the council of the city. (Ord. No. 1997-4, § 3, 5-5-1997) Sec. 2-56. - Agenda for council meetings. All regular monthly meetings of the city council shall be conducted according to the following rules and regulations: (1) The clerk shall prepare an agenda for the regular monthly meetings of the city council. In the event that a regular monthly meeting is continued to a later date, the council shall take up the remainder of the agenda in the order prepared unless there is good cause to deviate from the order of the agenda. (2) Before any special called meeting of the city council may be held, the city council members shall be given at least 48 hours' notice of such meeting. Only the matters presented in the notice shall be heard at any special called meeting. Any member may waive his lack of sufficient notice, and any member attending any special called meeting shall automatically waive his lack of sufficient notice unless he objects at the beginning of the meeting to such lack of notice. (3) Except as is otherwise set out herein, the edition of Robert's Rules of Order currently on file with the city clerk shall govern the conduct of the meeting. (4) The clerk will prepare an agenda and provide a copy of the same to the mayor and each member of the council by the Saturday prior to the regular monthly meeting of the council. Any councilmember failing to receive such agenda may waive his lack of timely receipt of a notice of the agenda, and the same shall be considered waived automatically if said councilmember does not object immediately upon the opening of the regular meeting by the person conducting the meeting. (5) Any person or group of persons desiring to be heard on any matter by the city council shall follow the following rules and procedures: a. The city clerk must be notified prior to 12:00 noon on the Friday before the regular scheduled monthly meeting of each person who desires to speak to the council and the matter about which the person wishes to speak. b. Any person who later discovers that he will not be able to attend the meeting must notify the clerk before 12:00 noon on the day of said meeting that they wish to have their name withdrawn from speaking at said meeting. c. Any person who notifies the clerk that they wish to speak at the next regular monthly meeting of the city council and who fails to attend said meeting without notifying the clerk prior to 12:00 noon on the day of said meeting 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 45/321 shall not be allowed to speak on the issue requested at any subsequent meeting of the city council for a period of one year from the date that said person was scheduled to speak. The mayor and city council can waive this restriction only if the reason for failing to notify the clerk within the required time was due to a dire emergency or if in the opinion of the mayor and city council there would be a manifest abuse of justice not to hear the person on the issue involved. d. Any person or group of persons desiring to be heard by the council who fails to notify the clerk by 12:00 noon on the Friday before the regular scheduled meeting shall not be heard by the council at that meeting but may be heard by the council at the next regular monthly meeting if said person or group requests to be heard at that next meeting. e. Any person speaking on an issue at a city council meeting shall not be allowed to speak for longer than five minutes on the issue in question. Provided, however, that any person speaking on an issue may continue to answer any questions by any city council member or the mayor. f. Any group of persons who wishes to be heard by the council on any particular issue shall collectively be limited to a speaking period of not more than 20 minutes regardless of the number of individuals wishing to speak on that issue. Provided, however, that if a group of people wishes to speak for and another group of people wishes to speak against a certain issue, then each side shall be allowed to speak for no more than 20 minutes. Provided, further, that no one individual shall be allowed to speak for more than five minutes on any given issue unless said individual is giving an answer to a question presented by the mayor of a member of the city council. (6) The mayor, or the mayor pro tem in the mayor's absence, shall be allowed to deviate from the order of the agenda established by the clerk due to the concerns of citizens who wish to speak on an issue and may further change the order of the agenda for any other reason at his discretion. (Ord. No. 1997-4, § 4, 5-5-1997) Sec. 2-57. - Rules for enaction of ordinances. (a) All ordinances shall be introduced at a first reading at an official council meeting. Each ordinance shall be in writing and in the form required for final adoption, except as otherwise provided herein. (b) The enacting clause on each ordinance shall be "The Council of the City of Ty Ty hereby ordains …," or such similar enacting language which shall be in every ordinance. (c) Any councilmember may introduce any ordinance and said ordinance shall be read at a regular or special meeting of the city council. The reading may be silent by each member of the council if so approved by the council or waived by unanimous vote if the ordinance has been received and read by all members prior to the meeting. (d) 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 46/321 Each ordinance shall be adopted or rejected by the city council in accordance with these rules. (e) No ordinance may be adopted on the same day that it is introduced, except for emergency ordinances, which procedures must be complied with according to section 3.18 of the official Charter. (f) Even though the writing is required to be in the form for final adoption when presented at the meeting, the following shall apply to any changes to the written form of the ordinance presented at the meeting for the first reading: (1) Any clerical errors, any obvious errors in construction, and any corrections that are not material changes to the ordinance may be made by having the same retyped before the final adoption of the ordinance without further vote or approval by the council. (2) Material changes may be made to the ordinance at the first reading only by the council voting to change the ordinance by a specific vote setting out the changes to the ordinance. Even though the writing itself will not be officially changed until later, upon an affirmative vote by the council to approve the ordinance as amended at its first reading, the ordinance will be deemed to meet the requirement of being in writing and in the form required for the final adoption. Subsequent thereto, the city clerk and/or the city attorney may draft the exact language to conform the writing to the amendments that were duly adopted by the council even though the same may not have been reduced to writing at that time. (3) Regardless of the foregoing rules and procedures, any ordinance that is presented for a second and final reading and is duly adopted and approved by the city council shall thereafter be considered a valid ordinance even though the ordinance contains written modifications thereto if the ideas and concept of those modifications were discussed at the first or a subsequent meeting and duly approved by the council. It is the intention of this section that the adoption of any ordinance in its final form at a second reading shall cure any procedural or other inadequacies related to said ordinance unless there is a manifest injustice created by the enaction of said ordinance related to those changes since it is the intention of the council that any ordinance adopted on its final reading should be presumed to be valid and should not be changed except in very rare and unusual circumstances. (Ord. No. 2000-03, 7-3-2000) Sec. 2-58. - Title. Sections 2-58 through 2-64 shall be known and may be cited as the "Date of City Council Meeting Ordinance." (Ord. No. 2001-8, § I, 12-3-2001) Sec. 2-59. - Jurisdiction. Sections 2-58 through 2-64 shall govern the city council as well as the city citizens so long as these sections are not amended or repealed. (Ord. No. 2001-8, § II, 12-3-2001) 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 47/321 Sec. 2-60. - Purpose and findings. The purpose of sections 2-58 through 2-64 is to amend all previous ordinances and to establish the date and time for the official regular city council monthly meetings of the city. In addition, these sections are to carry out the purposes and intents of section 3.13 of the City Charter which requires the city council to hold regular scheduled meetings at such times and places as prescribed by ordinance. (Ord. No. 2001-8, § III, 12-3-2001) Sec. 2-61. - Regular meetings. Unless the date for a regular meeting falls on a national holiday, and except as otherwise provided herein, all regular monthly meetings of the city council shall be held on the first Monday of each month. (Ord. No. 2001-8, §§ 1—4, 12-3-2001) Sec. 2-62. - Labor Day. (a) Since the first Monday of September each year is Labor Day and a national holiday, the regularly scheduled city council meeting for the month of September shall be held on the Tuesday following the first Monday in September. (b) In the event that any other national holiday, state holiday, or official observance occurs on the first Monday in a month, the mayor at his discretion shall have the authority to move the city council meeting to the Tuesday following the first Monday in that month; or if the mayor deems it inappropriate, then the meeting shall be moved to the second Monday in the month to ensure that a quorum will be present at said meeting. (Ord. No. 2001-8, §§ 1—4, 12-3-2001) Sec. 2-63. - Quorum. (a) If it appears to the mayor, or in his absence the mayor pro tem, that there will not be a quorum at any regularly scheduled monthly city council meeting, then the mayor shall have the authority in advance to schedule the regular monthly city council meeting for the day following the regularly scheduled meeting; or if it appears that the circumstances are such that the meeting cannot be held at that time, then the meeting can be rescheduled for the second Monday in the month at the discretion of the mayor, or in his absence the mayor pro tem. (b) In the event that a quorum does not appear for any regular monthly city council meeting, then the meeting shall automatically be rescheduled for the day following the regular monthly city council meeting unless it appears that a quorum will not be present at that time, in which event the presiding officer present at the meeting shall reschedule the meeting for the next following Monday or at such other time as the presiding officer deems is the most appropriate time for the meeting to be held if it does not appear that the next Monday is an appropriate time for said meeting. (Ord. No. 2001-8, §§ 1—4, 12-3-2001) Sec. 2-64. - Meeting time. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 48/321 (a) Any regularly scheduled meeting of the city council shall take place at 7:30 p.m., and the meeting shall continue thereafter until the business is completed or until a motion is adopted to continue the meeting until a later date. (b) Any meeting that is continued shall be held at such time as the city council shall agree by a majority vote of those present at the meeting in which said meeting was continued. (c) If it appears that the regular starting time for a meeting is inappropriate or would be beneficial to one or more of the councilmembers to change the meeting time on any particular meeting, then and in that event, the mayor shall have the authority to change the time of the meeting; but in no event shall any regular scheduled meeting begin after 8:30 p.m. on any given night. (Ord. No. 2001-8, §§ 1—4, 12-3-2001) Sec. 2-65. - Cancelled meetings; called meetings. If it appears to the mayor, or in his absence the mayor pro tem, that there are no material issues to be presented at a regularly scheduled monthly city council meeting, then the mayor shall have the authority in advance to cancel said meeting. In such event, the city clerk shall notify the councilmembers that the meeting has been cancelled. Should the mayor or any councilmember decide that there is an issue that needs to be handled before the next regularly scheduled monthly meeting, then and in that event, the mayor shall schedule a special called meeting at a time when it appears that there would be a quorum at said meeting. Otherwise, there will be no need to make up the regularly scheduled meeting that was cancelled. Secs. 2-66—2-83. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES Sec. 2-84. - Title. Sections 2-84 through 2-87 shall be known and may be cited as the "Nepotism Ordinance for the City of Ty Ty." (Ord. No. 2001-7, § I, 12-3-2001) Sec. 2-85. - Jurisdiction. Sections 2-84 through 2-87 shall govern the city and its residents so long as these sections are not amended or repealed. (Ord. No. 2001-7, § II, 12-3-2001) Sec. 2-86. - Purpose and findings. The purpose of this article is to establish a policy and procedure for the hiring of employees and to prohibit certain blood relatives from being employed by the City of Ty Ty. (Ord. No. 2001-7, § III, 12-3-2001) Sec. 2-87. - Nepotism prohibited. (a) 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 49/321 It is hereby prohibited that the city shall not hire any employee on a fulltime basis who is related by blood or marriage within the fourth degree of civil reckoning to any existing member of the city council or any fulltime paid employee of the city. (b) No person may be appointed as a city councilmember to fill a vacant seat in the city council if such new member would violate the nepotism rule set out in subsection (a) of this section. Provided, however, that should someone within the fourth degree of civil reckoning to an existing city councilmember run for office and be elected to said office by the citizens of the city, then said individual shall be permitted to serve on the city council with the other city councilmember who is related within the fourth degree of civil reckoning. (c) This nepotism prohibition shall not apply to any volunteers or any irregular parttime help. (d) A fulltime employee shall be considered as any employee who works more than 20 hours per week on a regular basis. (e) Nothing contained herein shall prevent relatives within the prohibited degree of civil reckoning to be hired for shortterm projects engaged in by the city. (Ord. No. 2001-7, § 3, 12-3-2001) Secs. 2-88—2-110. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - ZONING Sec. 2-111. - Zoning ordinance adopted. The "Zoning Ordinance for the City of Ty Ty, Georgia," adopted July 6, 1999, is attached hereto as "Appendix A" for convenience and is incorporated herein verbatim by reference thereto.

div.head: Chapter 4 - ADVERTISING
div.p: Sec. 4-1. - Advertising material and flyers; distribution; bill posting. (a) Defined. Bill posting, distributing advertising material, and distributing any other flyers or printed material in the city shall be construed to include and shall include posting, tacking, painting, circulation from house to house, business to business, or distributing upon the streets any advertising matter, bills, posters, pictures, or any other things, matter, or device whatsoever advertising the business of any person and shall also include any other type of printed material. (b) Exceptions. This section shall not apply to: (1) Sign painters painting store, office, or other signs. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 50/321 (2) Public officers or attorneys posting legal notices in the manner and places prescribed by law. (3) Any governmental body or unit, including the city or county. (4) Any church or society, for religious or other benevolent purposes, provided the persons distributing the bills or advertisements receive no compensation for the same. (c) Public improvement or structure. It shall be unlawful to paint, print, post, or in any other way affix a picture, bill, or advertising matter of any kind or any other kind of printed material upon any post, pole, hydrant, curb, sidewalk, or other public improvement or structure without first obtaining the permission of the city clerk. (d) Public streets or grounds. No person, entity, or business shall paint, print, post, or in any way affix any picture, bill, advertising matter, or any other printed literature of any kind upon any pole or mast in any street or alley or on any wire or cable incidental thereto or upon any tree or any structure or erection of any kind within the limits of any public street or grounds of the city, whether permission thereof has been granted by the owner or otherwise. (e) Building or object. No person, entity, or business shall paint, print, post, or in any way affix any picture, bill, advertising matter, or printed material of any kind upon any post, fence, billboard or signboard upon any building, erection, or structure of any kind within the city unless the building or object upon which the same is placed is the property or under control of the person putting up said material, or unless the consent of the owner or the person in control thereof has first been obtained. (Ord. No. 1992-2, § 2—5, 1-20-1992) Sec. 4-2. - Littering; advertising material classified as litter; exceptions. The following applies to advertising material: (1) Postings and distributions. No bill poster, advertising distributor, or distributor of printed material shall scatter or throw any old bills or waste material removed from billboards on the surface of any public street or way or the surface of any private grounds, and the same shall constitute litter. (2) Throwing and scattering material. No person, entity, or business shall loosely scatter or throw any bills, advertising matter, or other printed materials on the surface of the public streets or ways of the public grounds of the city or within the yards of private residences. The throwing of any paper, bills, flyers, or other advertising matter shall be classified as litter. (3) 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 51/321 Unsecured, loose material unlawful. It shall be unlawful, even after obtaining a license to do so, to tack, post, or in any other way attach any advertisements, handbills, or other printed materials to any wall post or other place in such a manner that they are not secured or fastened and/or may be loosened or blown about by the wind under normal circumstances. (4) Advertisements must be delivered personally or by mail. It shall be unlawful for any merchant or other person, entity, or business by himself or his employees to place or deposit in the streets of the city or in any of the yards of persons owning property in this city any handbills or other advertisements. All advertisements and handbills shall be delivered personally or by mail. (5) Exception for property owners' subscriptions. Provided, however, that this chapter shall not apply to any advertising matter or printed materials for which a resident, business, or landowner subscribes for the distribution of said literature and if the owner or person entitled to possession of the property requests that said material be delivered to that residence, then the material shall not be classified as litter. Any person, entity, or business distributing such material upon request of the city shall provide a current list of subscribers in the city. Any such distributor must update its list at least every six months. If false information is given to the city by such distributor or should the distributor fail to maintain a current subscriber list, then it shall be considered a violation of this chapter. If the distributor receives a written notice from the city of such violation, the distributor may not distribute any other material in the city until such errors are corrected and, if the distributor after receipt of notice continues to distribute its materials, then each picture, bill, advertising matter, or printed material of any kind that is distributed even to subscribers shall be considered litter and shall be a violation of this chapter. In addition, any distributor shall be responsible for removal of unwanted material distributed, and failure to do so shall be a violation of this chapter. (Ord. No. 1992-2, § 6—10, 1-20-1992) Sec. 4-3. - Handbills and advertising matter. (a) It shall be unlawful to place in or on any automobile in the city any handbill, circular, pamphlet, poster, or other literature except with express permission of the owner or occupant of such automobile. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to place on private property any handbill, circular, pamphlet, poster, or other literature except with express permission of the owner of the property or intended recipient. (c) It shall be unlawful for any person to tack, post, or nail any paper, metal wood, or other signs for advertising material of any character on any tree or telegraph, telephone or electric light pole, or on any street or alley within the city. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. I, § 9, 8-5-2002)

div.head: Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 52/321 State Law reference— Selling of alcohol is not a right in the state of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-1. Sec. 6-1. - Title. This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Alcoholic Beverage Ordinance." (Ord. No. 1998-1, § 1, 5-4-1998) Sec. 6-2. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Alcoholic beverage means all alcohol meant for consumption, distilled spirits, beer, malt beverages, wine, or fortified wine. Distilled spirits, beer, malt beverages, wine, and fortified wine shall have the definitions as established by O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2 et seq., and as amended from time to time. Legal age means the age established by O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23, as amended from time to time, as the age below which alcoholic beverages may not lawfully be sold to, furnished to, purchased by, or possessed by a person. (Ord. No. 1998-1, § 4, 5-4-1998) Sec. 6-3. - Purpose and findings. This chapter and the restrictions contained herein are imposed and designed for the protection of the public health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city. It is the further purpose of this chapter to establish the policy related to alcoholic beverages and their sale, use, and possession within the jurisdiction of the city. The city council, after reviewing various articles and studies which the council deems to be sufficient, finds that there is a great likelihood that the sale and use of alcoholic beverages in the city would cause an increase in crime, destruction of property, and endangering the lives of its citizens. (Ord. No. 1998-1, § 3, 5-4-1998) Sec. 6-4. - Jurisdiction. This chapter shall govern all persons and their actions while located within the city. (Ord. No. 1998-1, § 2, 5-4-1998) Sec. 6-5. - Overlay policy. It is hereby deemed to be against the public policy of the citizens and government of the city for any person or entity to sell alcoholic beverages in the city. (Ord. No. 1998-1, § 5, 5-4-1998) Sec. 6-6. - Regulations and restrictions. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person to violate any of the following provisions: (1) It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to sell any alcoholic beverage within the city limits. Each bottle or container of wine, beer, malt beverage, or other alcoholic beverage that is sold in violation of this chapter shall 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 53/321 be considered a separate offense punishable as hereinafter provided. (2) The city shall not issue any license nor shall it ever set any standard for issuing a license to sell any type of alcoholic beverages in the city. Should any business that has a business license violate any provisions of this chapter, then said business license to practice business in the city shall, upon a proper finding of such by any court, be revoked, and said business shall not be reissued an occupation license or business license for a period of at least one year thereafter. (3) It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any minor who is under the legal age to possess or have under his control any alcoholic beverage within the city limits, except for small amounts (less than one ounce in any 24-hour period) used in the observance of religious services. (4) It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for alcoholic beverages to be given to, turned over to, furnished to, delivered to, or sold to a person under the legal age by any person or entity within the city limits, except for small amounts of less than one ounce in any 24-hour period used in the observance of religious services. (5) It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for anyone to possess any type of alcoholic beverage in any container that is not sealed (i.e., that is in an open container) while said person is on a street, in any other public place, or in any business establishment that is open to the public within the city limits. (Ord. No. 1998-1, § 6, 5-4-1998)

div.head: Chapter 8 - ANIMALS
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority to provide animal control services, Ga. Const. Art. IX, § II, ¶ III. Sec. 8-1. - Joint animal control ordinance. The "City of Tifton/Tift County, Ty Ty, Omega Animal Control Ordinance" adopted January 3, 2005, is attached hereto as "Appendix C" for convenience and is incorporated herein verbatim by reference thereto.

div.head: Chapter 10 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authorization to provide building, housing, plumbing, and electrical codes, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(12). ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 54/321 Sec. 10-1. - Building permits. (a) It shall be unlawful to commence the excavation of filling of any lot for any construction of any building, or to commence construction or moving or alteration of any building, or to commence the development of land for use not requiring a building until the city clerk or the person designated by the county to issue such building permits has issued a building permit for such work. So long as the city has an intergovernmental contract for building inspections with the county, then said county's building inspection department or the person designated to issue permits shall issue such building permit for such work. (b) The mayor and council, after notice to the builder and/or owner of the structure built or being built of the violation of this section, may condemn the structure and forbid its occupancy. The council, upon discovery that a building permit has not been issued by the city clerk or the person in charge of issuing permits in the county, after notice to the builder and/or owner of the structure built or being built that there is a violation of this section, may condemn the structure and forbid its occupancy. (Ord. of 12-18-1973) Sec. 10-2. - Inspection fees and services. (a) A fee schedule for inspections and permits within the city shall be established by the county from time to time. (b) The inspector for the county shall also be the inspector for the city. (Ord. of 12-16-1991(1)) Sec. 10-3. - Standard codes. The most recent editions of the following codes are hereby adopted by reference as though they were copied herein fully: (1) NFPA (National Fire Protection Association) Life Safety Code 101, 1985 edition; (2) International Building Code (ICC); (3) National Electrical Code (NFPA); (4) International Fuel Gas Code (ICC); (5) International Mechanical Code (ICC); 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 55/321 (6) International Plumbing Code (ICC); (7) International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings (ICC); (8) International Energy Conservation Code (ICC); (9) International Fire Code (ICC); (10) International Existing Building Code (ICC); (11) International Property Maintenance Code (ICC); and (12) Any other codes deemed appropriate by the board for the safety and welfare of the state's citizens. (Ord. of 12-16-1991(2), § 1) Sec. 10-4. - Intergovernmental agreement. The city has entered into an intergovernmental agreement or contract (building inspection) with the county to provide all services related to the construction of buildings to ensure that all such buildings comply with federal and state laws. This contract was originally effective as of January 1, 1992, and said contract and any and all amendments are hereby approved and shall continue until terminated by either the city or county. Sec. 10-5. - Duties. (a) So long as the intergovernmental agreement with the county is in effect, it shall be the duty of the county to ensure that all buildings in the city are up to code and comply with federal and state law. (b) Within said codes when reference is made to the duties of certain officials named therein, that designated official in the city who has duties corresponding to those of the named official in said codes shall be deemed to be the responsible official insofar as enforcing the provisions of said codes are concerned. (c) There shall be appointed, through a cooperative agreement with the county, a building officer to act as chief enforcing officer for those standard codes outlined in section 10-3, and as such it shall be his duty to inspect all buildings and premises when, in his judgment, life and property will be protected thereby and to ensure compliance with the standard codes. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 56/321 (Ord. of 12-16-1991(2), §§ 2—4) Sec. 10-6. - Enforcement officer. The county chief enforcement officer and his staff are hereby appointed as the chief enforcement officer and staff for the city for any buildings constructed within the city. Sec. 10-7. - Fees. So long as the intergovernmental agreement is in effect, all fees and costs related to permits and construction problems shall be set by the county, and the county shall be entitled to receive all such fees for handling the process for the city, all as is set out in the intergovernmental agreement. Sec. 10-8. - Manner of establishing fees. There will be established an equitable and consistent manner of establishing building permit fees, moving of building or structure fees, demolition permit fees, and other fees as provided by the standard codes. (Ord. of 12-16-1991(2), § 5) Sec. 10-9. - Courts. Any violation of any federal or state codes related to any buildings or their construction may be enforced by the county on behalf of the city without the need or the intervention or involvement of the city unless otherwise required by law or unless the city council at a meeting determines that it wishes to get actively involved in such litigation. Secs. 10-10—10-36. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - WATER CONSERVATION FOOTNOTE(S): --- (2) --- State Law reference— Requirements for toilets, shower heads, faucets, etc., O.C.G.A. § 8-2-3. Sec. 10-37. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Commercial means any type of building other than residential. Construction means the erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation or in connection with making an addition to an existing building and shall include the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable, or obsolete faucet, showerhead, toilet, or urinal in an existing building. Residential means any building or unit of building intended for occupancy as a dwelling but shall not include a hotel or motel. (Ord. No. 1991-1, § 1, 2-4-1991) Sec. 10-38. - Residential construction. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 57/321 No construction may be initiated within the city for any residential building of any type which: (1) Employs a gravity tank-type, flushometer-valve, or flushometer-tank toilet that uses more than an average of 1.6 gallons of water per flush; (2) Employs a shower head that allows a flow of more than an average of 2.5 gallons of water per minute at 60 pounds per square inch of pressure; (3) Employs a urinal that uses more than an average of 1.0 gallon of water per flush; (4) Employs a lavatory faucet or lavatory replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 2.0 gallons of water per minute; or (5) Employs a kitchen faucet or kitchen replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 2.5 gallons of water per minute. (Ord. No. 1991-1, § 2, 2-4-1991) Sec. 10-39. - Commercial construction. There shall be no construction of any commercial building of any type initiated within the city which does not meet the requirements of section 10-38(1) through (5). (Ord. No. 1991-1, § 3, 2-4-1991) Sec. 10-40. - Repairs and renovations. The requirements of section 10-38 shall apply to any residential construction and any commercial construction which involves the repair or renovation of or addition to any existing building when such repair or renovation of or addition to such existing building includes replacement of toilets or showers or both. (Ord. No. 1991-1, § 4, 2-4-1991) Sec. 10-41. - Exemptions. New construction and the repair or renovation of an existing building shall be exempt from the requirements of sections 10-38 through 10-40 when: (1) The repair or renovation of the existing building does not include the replacement of the plumbing or sewage system servicing toilets, faucets or showerheads within such existing buildings. (2) When such plumbing or sewage system within such existing building, because of its capacity, design, or installation would not function properly if the toilets, faucets or showerheads required by this article were 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 58/321 installed. (3) Such system is a well or gravity flow from a spring and is owned privately by an individual for use in such individual's personal residence. (4) Units to be installed are: a. Specifically designed for use by the handicapped. b. Specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or installation in a penal institution. c. Toilets for juveniles. (5) The owner, or his agent, of a building undergoing new construction or repair or renovation who is entitled to an exemption as specified in subsection (1), (2), (3) or (4) of this section shall obtain the exemption by applying at the office of the mayor of the city. A fee shall be charged for the inspection and issuance of such exemption. Such fee shall be established from time to time by the Tifton and Tift County Development Support Services and made available for examination in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. No. 1991-1, § 5, 2-4-1991) Secs. 10-42—10-67. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - HOUSE NUMBERING Sec. 10-68. - Title. This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Uniform House Numbering Ordinance for the City of Ty Ty." (Ord. No. 2004-2, § I, 5-3-2004) Sec. 10-69. - Jurisdiction. This article shall govern the city and its residents so long as this article is not amended or repealed. (Ord. No. 2004-2, § III, 5-3-2004) Sec. 10-70. - Purpose and findings. The purpose of this article is to uniformly assign and maintain house numbers and provide for easy identification of those numbers for the various purposes and to promote the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city. (Ord. No. 2004-2, § IV, 5-3-2004) 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 59/321 Sec. 10-71. - Penalty for violation. (a) The imposition of any such fine or imprisonment, or both, for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; and all such violators shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within the time as prescribed by the court having jurisdiction of such matter, and in the absence of any such completion time being fixed by the court, within a reasonable time after such violations occur, such reasonable time not to exceed ten days. (b) The application of any fine, imprisonment, or other penalty shall not be construed to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions or to be postpone any action required. (c) The remedies set out in this section for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this article shall not be deemed to be exclusive, but shall be cumulative of all other remedies, civil or criminal, provided by the laws of this state, or by the ordinances of the city. (Ord. No. 2004-2, § 10, 5-3-2004) Sec. 10-72. - Requirement. Every house, mobile home, apartment, business, building, or other structure having a street address number assigned to it under the system of numbering in the city shall display such number in compliance with the requirements of this article. Mobile home parks and apartment complexes, including duplex dwelling structures, shall also be required to have each individual lot number or apartment number displayed in a readily visible manner and in compliance with this article. All numbers for a lot in a mobile home park, apartments, and buildings located along a street shall be in sequence unless approved otherwise in writing by the city council. (Ord. No. 2004-2, § 3, 5-3-2004) Sec. 10-73. - Method. Street address numbers shall be prominently displayed as follows: (1) In cooperation with the county and at the request of the 911 emergency services, the city has obtained metal stakes with reflecting numbers for each building and lot wherein lot numbers have been established under the city's uniform house numbering plan as shown on the official chart and records of the city as of the end of March, 2004. The city will install said house numbers on each lot in such place, either on the road right of way or on the property of an owner, as the city deems most appropriate. In general the city will, but is not required to, place the metal stake containing the number on the right of way generally centered in front of any house located on the property. Each mobile home park shall have a number for the park located next to the road, but each lot shall have a separate number generally located next to the water meter. (2) After the initial placement of the metal stakes containing the numbers on each lot in the city, any additional lots that are created that shall have a structure located thereon shall require a metal stake with a number as set out for other lots on that same street or area. Any lot that has the metal stake removed or severely damaged shall be replaced within ten days. The owner and occupant of each building required to have a number shall pay for a new stake with the appropriate number located thereon, the same to be obtained through the city, and shall pay to 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 60/321 the city an installation fee plus the cost of the materials. Such fee shall be established from time to time by the city council and made available for examination at city hall. The city personnel shall thereafter install such new number in the appropriate location as established by the city. Any new stakes may be metal or of such other material as selected by the city. (3) The numbers shall be posted in English using Arabic (not Roman) numerals. The numbers shall be a minimum of three inches in height and shall be metal or such other material as approved by the city. Only the official stakes supplied by the city may be used unless another is approved or authorized by either the mayor or the maintenance superintendent of the city. (Ord. No. 2004-2, § 4, 5-3-2004) Sec. 10-74. - Tampering with a house number. No person, unless properly authorized by the city, shall remove or otherwise disturb any house number. All numbers, even those subsequently paid for by a property owner, shall be the property of the city. The property owner and occupant shall be held responsible for and shall reimburse the city for the loss or theft of any stake or house number. (Ord. No. 2004-2, § 5, 5-3-2004) Sec. 10-75. - Obstructions. No person shall place upon or about any house number any object, material, debris, or structure of any kind, nor shall the occupant allow any vegetation to grow up around any house number that shall prevent the number from being readily visible from the public street if the lot is located on a street or the roadway if the lot is located in a mobile home park. Shrubs, bushes, and flower beds must be trimmed to allow the house number to be easily seen by any emergency vehicle attempting to locate said property. (Ord. No. 2004-2, § 6, 5-3-2004) Sec. 10-76. - Record of numbers. The city shall keep a chart showing proper street numbers and shall assign to every lot the proper number by which a building is to be designated. The failure of the city to keep such a chart current, however, shall not prevent any lot owner from making sure that his house number is in place and visible at all times. (Ord. No. 2004-2, § 7, 5-3-2004) Sec. 10-77. - Obligation of owner. The obligation of complying with all of the provisions of this article shall be upon the owner of the property. The owner may designate an occupier of the property to take care of the requirements, but it is the property owner that is ultimately responsible and who will be prosecuted by the city if a violation occurs. Upon such violation, notice shall be given to the owner of the property or his agent specifying the particulars of the violation and requiring that such violation be brought into compliance with this article within ten calendar days upon receipt of such notice. Any adult occupying the property shall be considered an agent of the owner. Failure to comply within the ten calendar days shall be punishable, upon conviction, as hereinafter provided. (Ord. No. 2004-2, § 8, 5-3-2004) Sec. 10-78. - Building permits. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 61/321 No building permits shall be issued for any principal building until the owner or developer has procured from the city the official number of the premises and a metal number is installed properly thereon. (Ord. No. 2004-2, § 9, 5-3-2004)

div.head: Chapter 12 - BUSINESSES
div.p: ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Secs. 12-1—12-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OCCUPATIONAL LICENSE TAXES FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority to impose business and occupation taxes and regulatory fees, O.C.G.A. § 48- 13-5 et seq. Sec. 12-19. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Administrative fee means a component of an occupation tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax. Employee means an individual whose work is performed under the direction and supervision of the employer and whose employer withholds FICA, federal income tax, or state income tax from such individual's compensation or whose employer issues to such individual for purposes of documenting compensation a form IRS W-2 but not a form IRS 1099. An individual who performs work under the direction and supervision of one business or practitioner in accordance with the terms of a contract or agreement with another business which recruits such individual is an employee of the business or practitioner which issues to such individual for purposes of documenting compensation a form IRS W-2. Flea market. (1) The term "flea market" means any event: a. At which two or more persons offer personal property for sale or exchange; and b. At which a fee is charged for the privilege of offering or displaying personal property for sale or exchange; or c. At which a fee is charged to prospective buyers for admission to the area where personal property is offered or displayed for sale or exchange; or d. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 62/321 Regardless of the number of persons offering or displaying personal property or the absence of fees, at which used personal property is offered or displayed for sale or exchange if the event is held more than six times in any 12-month period. (2) The term "flea market" is interchangeable with and applicable to "swap meet," "indoor swap meet," or other similar terms regardless of whether these events are held inside a building or outside in the open. The primary characteristic is that these activities involve a series of sales sufficient in number, scope, and character to constitute a regular course of business. (3) The term "flea market" shall not mean and shall not apply to: a. Any event which is organized for the exclusive benefit of any community chest, fund, foundation, association, or corporation organized and operated for religious, educations, or charitable purposes, provided that no part of any admission fee or parking fee charged vendors or prospective purchasers or the gross receipts or net earnings from the sale or exchange of personal property, whether in the form of a percentage of the receipts or earnings, as salary, or otherwise, inures to the benefit of any private shareholder or person participating in the organization or conduct of the event; or b. Any event at which all of the personal property offered for sale or displayed is new, and all persons selling, exchanging, or offering or displaying personal property for sale or exchange are manufacturers or licensed retail or wholesale merchants. Location or office does not include a temporary work site which serves a single customer or project. Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession, or business for revenue-raising purposes. Person shall be held to include all sole proprietors, corporations, limited liability companies, partnerships, or any other form of business organization. However, for purposes of the occupation tax, any charitable nonprofit organization which utilizes at least 50 percent of its gross income for charitable or religious purposes shall not have to pay occupational taxes. The charitable nonprofit organization has the burden of proof of convincing the city that it utilizes at least 50 percent of its gross income for religious or charitable purposes. Practitioner of profession or occupation means one who by state law requires state licensure regulating such profession or occupation and shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. (Ord. No. 1995-8, § B, 12-4-1995; Ord. of 4-1-2002, § 2) Sec. 12-20. - Requirement. Each person engaged in any business, trade, profession, or occupation in the city, with a location in the city, shall pay an occupation tax for said business, trade, profession, or occupation, which tax and any applicable registration shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business. (Ord. No. 1995-8, § A, 12-4-1995) Sec. 12-21. - Administrative fee. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 63/321 A non-prorated, nonrefundable administrative fee shall be required on all business and occupation tax accounts for the initial start-up, renewal, or reopening of those accounts. The amount of the administrative fee shall be as established from time to time by the city council and set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, available for examination at city hall. (Ord. No. 1995-8, § C, 12-4-1995) Sec. 12-22. - Tax rate. An occupation tax shall be levied upon those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations within the city limits based upon the number of employees of the business or practitioner. The tax rate determined by number of employees by each business, trade, profession, or occupation may be developed and updated from time to time by the city council. (Ord. No. 1995-8, § D, 12-4-1995; Ord. of 9-8-1998, § 2) Sec. 12-23. - Registration. Each person or business shall file in writing on such forms as required or requested by the city clerk a notarized statement (hereafter referred to as "registration") setting forth the number of employees working for said person or business in the preceding 12 months. The number of employees, for which a registration is required to be filed and listed with the city, shall be the largest number of employees working for said person or business during every calendar month of the preceding calendar year, and the occupation tax shall be based upon that number of employees. For example, if a business has only 50 employees from January through November but employs 101 employees during December, then the business must pay an occupation tax at the rate required for 101 employees. (Ord. No. 1995-8, § E, 12-4-1995; Ord. of 9-8-1998, § 3) Sec. 12-24. - Separate business locations. Where a person conducts business in more than one fixed location, each location or place shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of the occupation tax. (Ord. No. 1995-8, § F, 12-4-1995) Sec. 12-25. - Interest and penalties for delinquent taxes. (a) Each business shall pay to the city the occupation tax provided herein unless otherwise specifically provided herein. Said occupation tax shall be payable on January 1 of each year, and if not paid by January 31 of that year, each business shall incur interest on delinquent occupation taxes and administrative fees at a rate of 1.5 percent per month. Should any occupation tax or license fee remain due and unpaid for 90 days from the due date, the person liable for the tax or fee shall be subject to and shall pay a penalty of ten percent of the tax or fee due, said penalty to be in addition to the occupation tax. (b) Should any person or business covered hereunder fail to file the registration as required by section 12-23 by January 31 of any calendar year, then the occupation tax for that business shall conclusively be presumed to be for the highest rate listed in the schedule of rates, regardless of the number of employees employed by said business. (c) 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 64/321 On any new profession, trade, or business the administrative fee required by section 12-21 and the occupation tax shall be delinquent if not obtained and paid within 30 days following the commencement of the business. Any new business commenced on or after July 1 in any year shall pay an occupation tax for the remaining portion of the year at a rate of 50 percent of the tax imposed for the entire year. Failure of any new business to register or pay the administrative fee or pay the occupation tax within 30 days following the commencement of the business shall result in said business being in a delinquent status. (d) Any business that was in existence prior to January 1 of any calendar year and which fails to register or pay any fees required by this article by January 31 of that year shall result in said business being in a delinquent status. (e) The registration required in section 12-23 shall be accepted by the city clerk if the registration is in proper form and filed appropriately.
