(b) The public officer may determine, under existing Code regulations, that a building, dwelling, or structure is vacant, dilapidated, and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes upon personal observation or report of a law enforcement agency and evidence of drug crimes being committed. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. IV, pt. III, § 8, 8-5-2002) Sec. 20-130. - Actions. Any action taken pursuant to sections 20-121 and 20-125 through 20-129 shall be in conformance with the procedures set forth at O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7 and 41-2-17. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. IV, pt. III, § 10, 8-5-2002)

div.head: Chapter 22 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Disorderly conduct, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-39; public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41; authorization for local ordinances regulating and controlling litter, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-48. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 136/321 Secs. 22-1—22-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - DISORDERLY CONDUCT Sec. 22-21. - Title. These regulations shall be known as the "Disorderly Conduct Ordinance." (Ord. No. 1997-3, § 1, 5-5-1997) Sec. 22-22. - Prohibited actions. It shall be unlawful and any person shall be guilty of disorderly conduct if that person commits any of the following acts: (1) Speaks or utters while at the city hall any lewd or obscene words of epithets. A sign may be placed in the city hall warning of this prohibition, but the failure to have such a sign shall not excuse or acquit any person who violates this provision of this section. (2) Acts in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another person. (3) Endangers lawful pursuits of another person by acts of violence, angry threats, or abusive conduct. (4) Causes, provokes, or engages in any filth, brawl, or riotous conduct so as to endanger the life, limb, health, or property of another or public property. (5) Collects in groups of three or more persons for any unlawful purpose. (6) Assembles with another person for the purpose of engaging in any fraudulent scheme, device, or trick to obtain any valuable thing in any place or from any person in the city or to aid or abet such action. (7) Goes onto any place or property with knowledge that there will be an illegal sale or possession of alcoholic beverages, narcotics, or dangerous drugs is practiced, allowed, or tolerated on said property. (Ord. No. 1997-3, § 4, 5-5-1997) Secs. 22-23—22-46. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES Sec. 22-47. - Title. These regulations shall be collectively known and may be cited as the "Offenses—Miscellaneous Ordinance for the City of Ty Ty, Georgia," but each individual section may be referred to separately as a separate ordinance 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 137/321 with the heading listed on each separate provision. (Ord. No. 1997-6, § 1, 8-4-1997) Sec. 22-48. - Jurisdiction. These regulations shall govern all persons and their actions while located within the city. (Ord. No. 1997-6, § 2, 8-4-1997) Sec. 22-49. - Purpose. These regulations and restrictions are imposed and designed for the protection of the public health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city. It is the further purpose of this article to establish that the offenses listed herein will constitute a nuisance, a threat to the morals, or an interference with the rights of others located within the confines of the city. (Ord. No. 1997-6, § 3, 8-4-1997) Sec. 22-50. - Regulations and restrictions. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for a person to violate any of the following provisions: (1) Loitering. It shall be unlawful for any person to idle, loiter, or loaf on the streets, sidewalks, alleys, lanes, highways, parks, or in the vicinity immediately outside of any public or private building. The term "idle," "loiter," or "loaf," as used in this section, shall be any conduct such as standing, sitting, or laying either individually or with others on any real property in the city without the express permission of the owner or manager of the property. It shall further be considered idling, loitering, and loafing to stand, sit, or congregate outside a business open to the public without a legitimate business purpose. A person may not stand, sit, or lay on such business's property after having completed said person's business. (2) Littering. It shall be unlawful for any person to litter, place, or throw rubbish, trash, debris, garbage, junk, or refuse on or upon any of the streets, alleys, lanes, or any other city property. (3) Loud noises. It shall be unlawful for any person to use any loud speaker, amplifier, megaphone, sound truck, or any other mechanical or electrical device to make loud and unnecessary noises in the city without a written permit from the city clerk. The same shall be considered a nuisance. (4) Public intoxication. It shall be unlawful for any person to be intoxicated on the streets, alleys, lanes, or in any public place located within the city. (5) Skating. It shall be unlawful to skate on roller skates, roller blades, skate boards, or any other similar type of instrument on any street, alley, or lane in the city. (6) 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 138/321 Slingshots. It shall be unlawful for any person to use a sling shot within the city. (7) Firearms. It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot any type of firearm or gun, including a pellet gun or BB gun, in the city. (Ord. No. 1997-6, § 4, 8-4-1997) Editor's note— A similar prohibition regarding litter may be found in Chapter 20, Nuisances, section 20-8(8).

div.head: Chapter 24 - SOLID WASTE
div.p: ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Secs. 24-1—24-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CLEAN COMMUNITY PROVISIONS Sec. 24-19. - Definitions. For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given in this section. The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and the enforcement of this article: Building materials means any material such as lumber, brick, plaster, gutters, or other substances accumulated as a result of repairs or additions to existing buildings, construction of new buildings, or demolition of existing structures. Bulk container means a metal container of not less than four cubic yards nor larger than eight cubic yards, made of watertight construction with doors opening on top and constructed so that it can be emptied mechanically by specially equipped trucks. Containers shall be kept covered at all times. Hereinafter upon the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, all new bulk containers shall meet these specifications. Business trash means any waste accumulation of dust, paper and cardboard, packing materials, rags or other accumulations, other than garbage or household trash, which are usually attendant to the operation of stores, offices and similar businesses. Commercial establishment means any retail, manufacturing, wholesale, institutional, religious, governmental, or other nonresidential establishment at which garbage or trash may be generated. Dead animals includes domestic and nondomestic animals. Disposal site means an area, location, tract of land, or facility used or intended to be used for the disposal of solid waste, putrescible waste, hazardous waste, or other waste, except it shall not include the land or facility used for the disposal of solid waste or other waste from a single-family dwelling in which the owner, occupant, or lessee of said land or facility resides. Garbage means the byproduct of animal or vegetable foodstuffs resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food, or other matter which is subject to decomposition, decay, putrefaction or the generation of noxious or offensive gases or odors, or which during or after decay, may serve as breeding or feeding material for flies, insects, or animals. Hazardous refuse means materials such as poison, acids, caustics, chemicals, infected materials, offal, fecal matter, including all manner of human or animal waste, and explosives. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 139/321 Household trash means every waste accumulation of paper, sweepings, dust, rags, bottles, cans or other matter of any kind, other than garbage, which is usually attendant to housekeeping. Independent company means any person or entity authorized by the city to collect trash or waste within the city limits other than the county or city. Industrial waste means all waste including solids, semi-solids, sludge, and liquids created by factories, processing plants, or other manufacturing enterprises. Litter means garbage, refuse, waste materials, or any other discarded, used, or consumed substance which is not handled as specified herein. Loading and unloading areas means space or area used by any moving vehicle for the purpose of receiving, shipping, and transporting goods, wares, commodities, and persons. Motor vehicle or vehicle means any motorized vehicle or trailer. Multiple residential unit means any duplex, apartment, group of apartments, or condominium used for dwelling places of more than one family. Owner means the owner, lessor, lessee, security interest holders, and all lienholders as shown on the records of the department of revenue. Refuse means solid waste accumulations consisting of garbage household trash, yard trash, and business trash as defined in this section. Refuse receptacle means a metal or plastic container for refuse, of substantial construction, with tightfitting lids, and provided with handles and/or wheels sufficient for safe and convenient handling. Such receptacles shall be of the size and nature set by the city council. Safety or health hazard means a condition of sufficient gravity and seriousness to threaten the health, welfare, or safety of the residents of the city or county. Scavenge means uncontrolled picking from discarded refuse materials. Single residential unit means any dwelling place occupied by one family. Tree and shrubbery trimmings means waste accumulation of tree branches, tree limbs, parts of trees, bushes, shrubbery, cuttings or clipping, or other usually created as refuse in the case of trees or bushes. Yard trash means waste accumulation of lawn, grass, or shrubbery cuttings or clippings and dry leaf rakings, free of dirt, rocks, large branches, and bulky or noncombustible material. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. I, § 2, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-20. - Licenses. It shall be unlawful for any person to collect solid waste within the city, except from his own residence or business or industrial property, without first obtaining a proper permit or license for such business operation from the state department of natural resources and authorized and approved by the city. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. I, § 3, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-21. - Collection. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 140/321 Collection of trash within the city by an independent company may be authorized and approved by the city by agreement with such company. Additional requirements established by said company must be complied with by any citizen who wishes to utilize such services. No citizen may be required to use such company, and the company may refuse to service any property for cause. All applicable provisions of this and all other applicable ordinances and laws must be complied with by any person or entity collecting trash or waste. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. I, § 4, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-22. - Receptacles and containers. (a) It shall be required of every person in possession, charge or control of any place in or from which business trash or industrial waste is accumulated or produced to provide and at all times to keep in a suitable place readily accessible to any public collection crews or private collection agencies, adequate and suitable receptacles and containers capable of holding all such waste materials which would ordinarily accumulate between the times of successive collections. The county public works, if applicable, and if not, the city, and if not, the independent company or companies authorized to collect trash by the city, shall determine the quantity and location of said receptacles and shall determine whether said receptacles and containers are serviceable. The county public works, if applicable, or the city, shall also notify any such persons that their receptacles and containers are not serviceable. Once so notified, such persons shall immediately make their receptacles and containers serviceable as requested by the county public works or said independent company. (b) All receptacles and containers as required in subsection (a) of this section shall be of safe construction and design and shall be maintained in good and serviceable condition at all times. Any receptacles or containers which do not conform to the provisions of this article, or which have ragged or sharp edges or any other defects likely to hamper or injure the person collecting the contents thereof or the public generally, and after proper notice have not been replaced, may be removed as refuse. (c) Every citizen utilizing the trash and/or waste pickup system of the county or an independent company shall comply with the then established requirements of the county or said independent company, and this article shall be deemed to incorporate any changes in such procedures that the county or said independent company may require while any citizen of the city is utilizing any such services. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. I, § 5, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-23. - Precollection practices. Regardless of which collection service is used, the following precollection practices shall be utilized: (1) Refuse. All refuse shall be placed and maintained in containers as specified in this article. All containers shall be kept covered at all times with tightfitting covers. (2) Garbage. All garbage being placed in containers for collection shall have drained from it all free liquid and should be wrapped, bagged, or enclosed in paper or plastic material. (3) 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 141/321 Household trash. All household trash shall be drained of all liquids prior to its deposit in refuse receptacles. (4) Injurious trash items. All waste material of an injurious nature, such as broken glass, light bulbs, sharp pieces of metal, fluorescent tubes, and television tubes, shall be securely wrapped to prevent injury to the collection crews. (5) Hazardous refuse and building materials. No hazardous refuse or building materials shall be placed in any receptacle used for collection by the county nor shall the same be collected by the city or the county. (6) Yard trash. Yard trash shall be accumulated upon the owner's property and located so as to accommodate convenient pickup, where pickup is available. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. I, § 6, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-24. - Storing of refuse and trash. All accumulations of refuse and trash shall be stored or placed for collection in accordance with the following provisions: (1) Public streets and private property. No person shall place any accumulations of refuse or trash in any street, median strip, alley or other public place of travel, nor upon any private property except as stated herein. (2) Blockage of storm drains. No person shall place any refuse, trash, refuse receptacles, or containers on, upon, or over any storm drain, or so close thereto as to be drawn by the elements into same. (3) Unauthorized accumulations. Any accumulation of refuse, junk, or trash items on any lot, property, premises, public street, alley or other public or private place not permitted by this article is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and is prohibited. Failure of the owner or occupant to remove and correct any such accumulation of refuse shall be deemed a violation of this article. (4) Junk. a. It shall be unlawful for any person to place or leave outside any building or dwelling any dilapidated furniture, appliance, machinery, equipment, junked motor vehicle, or other item which is either in a wholly or partially rusted, wrecked, junked, dismantled, or inoperative condition and which is not completely enclosed within a building or dwelling. Any such item which remains on the property of the occupant for a period of 30 days after notice of violation of this section shall be presumed to be abandoned and subject to being removed from the property by the city without further notice, and any such failure to remove such item shall be deemed a violation of this section. b. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 142/321 Subsection (4)a of this section shall not apply to: 1. Commercial establishments engaged in the repair, rebuilding, reconditioning or salvaging of equipment or furniture. For purposes of construction of this article, commercial establishments shall include any establishment licensed under any ordinance passed by the county requiring business licensing; and 2. Any properties zoned for agricultural use. c. While this provision shall not apply to commercial establishments as identified in subsection (4)b of this section, such commercial establishments shall be required to provide screening so as to prevent visual blight affecting adjoining properties. Such screening is to be a durable masonry or chainlink fence and hedge of sufficient opacity to provide a visual blind, designed to be compatible with the character of adjoining properties. Such screening shall be provided and maintained by the owner and his successors and assigns; and such fences and walls shall be at least six feet in height, but no greater than eight feet in height, measured from the ground along the common lot line of the adjoining properties. Hedges or comparable natural planting shall be of such variety that an average height of at least six feet could be expected by normal growth no later than three years from the time of planting. The owner shall be required to install screening within six months (5) Appliances. It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside any building in a place accessible to children any appliance, refrigerator, or other container of any kind which has an airtight snap lock or similar device without first removing the lock or door from said appliances, refrigerator, or container to such an extent that it is impossible for a child to obtain access to any airtight compartment thereof. This provision shall not be construed to allow the storage of abandoned appliances which is prohibited under the provisions of subsection (4) of this section. (6) Scavenging. No person other than the owner thereof, or an agent or employee of the county and/or the city or any company authorized to do so by the city, shall interfere with any container placed for the purpose of storing refuse pending collection, or remove or take any of the contents thereof, or remove any such container from the location where the same shall have been placed by the owner thereof. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. I, § 7, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-25. - Scattering of refuse and littering prohibited. (a) Persons. It shall be unlawful for any person to: (1) Throw or deposit any refuse into any public or private street or scatter refuse about or litter any public or private street, alley, or area or place; (2) Throw or deposit any refuse, trash, or debris in any stream, stream bed, or body of water; or 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 143/321 (3) Throw or deposit any refuse, trash, or debris on the private property of another. (b) Vehicles transporting materials. It shall be unlawful for any vehicle transporting loose materials within the city to transport same without suitable covers. This subsection shall not apply to the transportation of cotton, poultry, or livestock or silage or other feed grain used in the feeding of poultry or livestock. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. I, § 8, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-26. - Commercial establishments. All commercial establishments shall store their refuse in containers as specified in this article so as to eliminate wind-driven debris and unsightly litter in and about their establishments. Approved methods of containerization include refuse receptacles, bulk containers, and detachable containers. Spillage and overflow shall be immediately cleaned up by said establishment when and as it occurs. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. I, § 10, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-27. - Loading and unloading. All loading and unloading areas shall be provided with refuse receptacles for loose debris, paper, packaging materials, and other trash. The number of containers necessary for each area shall be as required to maintain clean, neat, and sanitary premises. The owner of the premises and the occupant thereof shall jointly and severally maintain surveillance to ensure that all litter is placed in the proper container and the area is kept clean. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. I, § 11, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-28. - Parking lots. (a) Owner to supply receptacles and maintain premises in sanitary condition. All parking lots and establishments with parking lots shall provide refuse receptacles. The city shall have the authority to determine the number and types or receptacles necessary to provide proper containerization. Such receptacles shall be weighted or attached to the ground as necessary to prevent spillage. It shall be the responsibility of the owner or the manager of the parking lot to maintain the lot in a clean and presentable condition, collect the refuse and trash deposited in such containers, and store this material in an approved location as hereinabove defined. (b) Obligation to use receptacles. It shall be the obligation of all persons using the parking areas to use such refuse receptacles or containers as in subsection (a) of this section provided for the purpose intended, and it shall be unlawful for any person to dump, scatter, or throw upon any such parking lot, and refuse, garbage, or trash of any kind. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. I, § 12, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-29. - Construction and demolition sites. The person in control of such construction sites shall use reasonable measures to prevent trash and litter from being deposited upon or blowing onto neighboring property. Construction materials or other debris deposited upon any public or private property as a result of construction or demolition shall be removed by the contractor 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 144/321 upon completion of the construction. No person or contractor shall bury building materials or trash on a construction site. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. I, § 13, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-30. - Collection practices. (a) Bulk container. Any commercial establishment that furnishes and maintains a bulk container suitable for handling by county equipment will be serviced by the county or other businesses authorized to do so by the city as herein stated, provided that said container shall be of sufficient size as specified and be approved for collection. Said containers shall at all times be kept clean, neat, painted, and in a good state of repair. Service shall be discontinued to establishments failing to maintain containers appropriately. Establishments utilizing bulk containers are responsible for repairing said containers for service, and no service shall be given to those establishments permitting objects, obstructions, or vehicles to hinder in any way the servicing of the said container. Cleaning up spilled materials shall be the responsibility of the property owner or occupant. (b) Holidays. Collections shall not be made on the following holidays unless otherwise specified by the county: New Year's Day, Martin Luther King, Jr. memorial holiday, Memorial Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day. (c) Industrial waste. Industrial waste shall be collected, removed, and disposed of by the operator of the factory, plant or enterprise creating or causing same. (d) Hazardous refuse. No hazardous refuse shall be placed in any receptacle used for collection of refuse by the county or city or anyone collecting normal trash or waste. Hazardous refuse must be collected only by collectors licensed to do so by the department of natural resources. (e) Building materials. Neither the county nor the city shall be responsible for the collecting or hauling of building material originating from private property preliminary to, during, or subsequent to the construction of new buildings of whatever type or from demolition of existing structures. Such material shall be removed by the owner of the property or by the contractor as soon as reasonably practicable after completion of the project and before landscaping. (f) Hazardous or combustible waste. Hazardous or liquid waste or highly combustible industrial waste shall not be disposed of in the county landfill. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. I, § 14, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-31. - Special refuse disposal. (a) Contagious disease material. The removal of clothing, bedding, or other refuse from homes or other places where highly infectious diseases have prevailed shall be performed under the supervision and direction of the 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 145/321 county health department. Such refuse shall not be placed in containers for county, city, or other normal trash and waste collection. (b) Hypodermic devices. No person shall dispose of or discard any hypodermic syringe, hypodermic needle or any instrument or device for making hypodermic injections before first breaking, disassembling, destroying, or otherwise rendering inoperable and incapable of reuse, such hypodermic syringe, needle, instrument, or device, and without safeguarding the disposal thereof, by wrapping or securing same in a suitable manner so as to avoid the possibility of causing injury to the collection person. Nothing in this provision shall be construed to allow the disposal of medical wastes by any person required to utilize designated methods of disposal under any laws or regulations promulgated by any local, state or federal department or agency charged with regulating disposal of medical waste. (c) Cardboard boxes and cartons. Prior to depositing refuse for collection in authorized containers or receptacles or in commercial containers, the person disposing of any such boxes or cartons or the person in charge of the premises shall collapse all cardboard boxes and cartons. The person in charge of the premises shall remove any Styrofoam or other packing materials therein contained prior to collapsing the boxes and cartons and shall take such measures as are necessary to prevent disbursal or blowing of cardboard on subject or onto adjoining properties and shall situate such containers or receptacles so as to accommodate pickup by the county or city or an independent company. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. I, § 15, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-32. - Vehicles for hauling refuse or trash. All persons who desire to haul refuse or trash over the county or city roads shall use a vehicle provided with a cover and operate it so as to prevent refuse from being dropped, blown, or spilled. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. I, § 16, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-33. - Responsibility of owners and agents. The owners or agents, tenants, or lessees of all residential units and commercial establishments shall be responsible for compliance with this article. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. I, § 17, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-34. - Maintenance of property. (a) Property. All owners or occupants of property shall maintain their property in a litter-free condition. (b) Sweeping into sidewalks or streets. No person shall sweep into or deposit in any street or sidewalk the accumulation of litter from any building or property. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. I, § 18, 8-5-2002) Secs. 24-35—24-58. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - DISPOSAL SITES 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 146/321 Sec. 24-59. - Authorized. All domestic and other acceptable refuse shall be delivered and deposited at authorized disposal sites in accordance with the directions and orders of the public works director or his representative in charge of operations. However, privately operated sites may be used for the inert disposal permits, as required by the regulations of the state department of natural resources. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. II, § 1, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-60. - Designated by signs. Public sites, if any, approved for the disposal of refuse shall be designated by appropriate signs posted near the roadside. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. II, § 2, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-61. - Operating hours. Authorized public disposal sites, if any, shall be operated at such times as are determined and posted at such sites by the county or city. During such hours, acceptable refuse generated in the city shall be received for disposal. It shall be a violation of this article for any person to deposit refuse outside the parameter of disposal sites when such sites are closed. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. II, § 3, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-62. - When use authorized; ownership of waste. No person shall enter a disposal site except when an attendant is present and during the hours and days prescribed in section 24-61. All materials delivered and deposited for disposal on the grounds or disposal sites shall be the property of the county if operated by the county and the city if operated by the city. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. II, § 4, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-63. - Unlawful actions regarding commercial dumpsters. It shall be a violation of this article for any person to: (1) Put household garbage, trash, or any other waste in a commercial dumpster within the city without permission from the owner of said dumpster; (2) Remove any article, trash, or other material from any commercial dumpster in the city without permission from the owner; or (3) Scatter material from a commercial dumpster around the commercial dumpster site. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. II, § 5, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-64. - Classification of refuse. (a) 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 147/321 Domestic refuse. The following types of refuse shall be classified as domestic refuse and shall be accepted for disposal: (1) Business trash, as defined in section 24-19 (2) Garbage, as defined in section 24-19 (3) Household trash, as defined in section 24-19; or (4) Refuse, as defined in section 24-19 (b) Industrial waste. The following types of waste shall be classified as industrial waste and shall not be accepted for disposal: (1) Hazardous refuse, as defined in section 24-19; or (2) Industrial waste, as defined in section 24-19 (c) Building materials. Building materials, as defined in section 24-19, shall be accepted for disposal upon payment of a fee which shall be determined by the county and shall be paid at the time such material is accepted for disposal. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. II, § 6, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-65. - Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or permit to be deposited on land under his ownership and control any refuse without first having obtained a disposal area permit as required by the regulations of the state department of natural resources, and acceptance of the site for such use and purpose by the city. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. II, § 7, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-66. - Owner's responsibility to maintain premises. It shall be the duty and responsibility of the owner of any private disposal site to keep the site in an orderly condition and maintained so as not to be a public nuisance or a menace to public health. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. II, § 8, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-67. - Right of entry for inspection. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 148/321 The county, city, or their designated representative, or authorized representative of the department of natural resources, shall be permitted to enter private disposal sites at any time during normal business hours for free and unhindered inspection to determine compliance with this chapter and all other pertinent laws and regulations. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. II, § 9, 8-5-2002) Sec. 24-68. - Burning prohibited. (a) No person shall set fire to, or burn, building materials, business trash, garbage, household trash, industrial waste, or litter, as those terms are defined in section 24-19. This shall not be construed to prevent small fires on construction sites for purposes of personal warmth. (b) Only the burning of natural vegetation (e.g., trees, brush, stumps and yard trash as defined in section 24-19) will be allowed within the political boundaries of the city subject to the following procedures, rules and regulations. Fireplaces and outdoor grills are specifically excepted. (c) Persons desiring to burn shall obtain a burn permit number from the state forestry commission, and all burning will be performed in compliance with the rules for quality control issued by the Georgia Department of Natural Resources, Environmental Protection Division, Air Protection Branch, and identified as chapter 391-3-1. (d) If the city, through its designated agent, determines that the conditions contained in subsections (a) through (c) of this section have not been met and that a danger to the health and welfare of the public is present during permitted burning, or any unpermitted burning is occurring, such person shall have the authority to require that any burning be discontinued. Should the party performing the burning refuse to discontinue upon request, the city's designated agent shall be authorized to contact the county sheriff's office who shall be authorized to take such action as reasonably necessary to discontinue the burning. (Ord. No. 2002-2, art. I, pt. II, § 10, 8-5-2002)

div.head: Chapter 26 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES
div.p: ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Secs. 26-1—26-15. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OPEN AIR EVENTS Sec. 26-16. - Title. This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Open Air Event Ordinance." (Ord. No. 2009-01, § I, 8-3-2009) Sec. 26-17. - Jurisdiction. This article shall govern all persons within the corporate limits or police jurisdiction of the city. (Ord. No. 2009-01, § II, 8-3-2009) Sec. 26-18. - Purpose and findings. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 149/321 The purpose of this article is to regulate and control any public events that are to be held outside, either on public or private property, that are open to the public. These regulations are for the health and safety of the residents of the city and all who might wish to attend such events. (Ord. No. 2009-01, § III, 8-3-2009) Sec. 26-19. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Open air event (hereinafter referred to as "event") means any organized activity having as its purpose entertainment, recreation, and/or education, such as a festival, carnival, or celebration, athletic events, races, concerts, parade or march, rally, trade show, or assembly which takes place on a public street, sidewalk, or right of way, or occurs on private property and impacts government services or negatively impacts on the citizens of Ty Ty. Sponsor is synonymous with the term "producer" and mean any person, group, or persons, organization, association, club, or other entity responsible for planning, producing, and conducting an event. Vendor means any person who engages in the sale to the public of any food or food products, goods, services, or merchandise of whatever nature, from any location, either mobile or stationary, on a temporary itinerant basis on any public street, sidewalk, or right-of way. The term "vendor" for this article shall not apply to any permanent business. (Ord. No. 2009-01, § 2, 8-3-2009) Sec. 26-20. - Permit required. (a) Except for activities sanctioned by the city, and except where otherwise permitted herein, it shall be unlawful for any person, group, organization, association, club, or other entity to conduct or cause to be conducted any event in the city without having obtained a valid permit for such event. (b) An event shall be limited to the specific geographic areas within which the event is to take place, and the sponsor of an event shall be responsible for the provision of police and sanitation services within the boundaries of the event and for a period of two hours past the conclusion of the event or until the area is cleared of all activities and structures related to such event. (c) Except for the clearing of the area, no event shall be allowed to continue beyond the time approved on the permit for the event. If no time is specified in the permit, then the event shall not run past 10:00 p.m. (d) The outermost boundaries of the event shall be fully and clearly delineated on a map or drawing no smaller in size than 8½ × 11 inches and shall be attached to the application for a permit. All streets and sidewalks shall be clearly delineated. (Ord. No. 2009-01, § 3, 8-3-2009) Sec. 26-21. - Application. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 150/321 (a) A sponsor of an event shall make application for a permit for such event to the clerk at the city hall. Application forms may be obtained from the clerk. (b) An application for an event should be filed at least 90 days prior to the date the event is scheduled to occur. However, no application shall be accepted earlier than one year prior to the date of the event. (c) The application shall be on a form as may be designated and changed from time to time by the city. Failure to fill out the application properly or completely may result in an automatic denial of the event. The application must contain the name and contact information on the sponsor; and unless the sponsor is an entity with which the mayor is familiar, the sponsor must also include an individual and the individual must present a driver's license or other form of photo identification which will be copies by the clerk of the city and attached to the application. The application must also include a basic plan, which plan must include but not be limited to the following: (1) The dates of the event. (2) A description of the event to be held. (3) The location of the event. (4) A list of the type of vendors that will be invited, if any. (5) Any streets or alleyways that will be affected by the event. (6) The times of opening and closing of the event. (7) The time that the vendors or other participants will be using the property to prepare for and close down the event. (8) Whether or not any electricity or water will be used. (9) Any city property or facilities that will need to be used. (10) 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 151/321 How many security personnel are going to be provided to ensure the control and safety of all persons attending the event. (At least one security personnel for every 100 people expected to attend the event is required.) (11) A plan for parking for those expected to attend and may be included on the map required to be attached to the application. (12) The number of temporary outdoor toilet facilities that will be present at the event (at least one toilet for every 200 persons expected is required). The locations of the toilet must be indicated on the map, and the mayor or his designee may change the location of the toilets at any time prior to the occurrence of the event. (Ord. No. 2009-01, § 4, 8-3-2009) Sec. 26-22. - Application fee. Except when waived by the mayor, a nonrefundable application fee of $25.00 shall be paid at the time the application for a permit is filed. Said fee shall be payable to the city by cash, money order, or cashier's check. In addition, should the sponsor require the city to provide either electricity or water, then and in that event, a deposit of $50.00 for water and $150.00 for electricity must also be paid with the application. If any electricity or water is used, the sponsor will be responsible for paying the cost of the electricity and water. The amount of the cost of the electricity and water will be determined by the city, and the sponsor shall pay the excess if any additional sums are owed, and the city shall refund the balance of the deposit if the cost is less than the amount of the deposit. (Ord. No. 2009-01, § 5, 8-3-2009) Sec. 26-23. - Council review. Each application shall be reviewed by the city council, and the city council must approve an application before the event may be held. The city must either issue a permit or deny the permit no later than 30 days prior to the date that the event is to occur. If the application is filed in a timely manner and the city fails to act on an application, then the permit shall be automatically denied. It is up to the sponsor to make sure that the issue is presented to the city council in a timely manner so that the decision can be made prior to 30 days before the event is to occur. (Ord. No. 2009-01, § 6, 8-3-2009) Sec. 26-24. - Emergency issue of permit. In extraordinary circumstances, the mayor or his designee shall be authorized to waive or otherwise expedite any or all of the review process and to issue an event permit upon payment by the sponsor of all applicable fees and costs for such event. (Ord. No. 2009-01, § 7, 8-3-2009) Sec. 26-25. - Liability. The sponsor of any event shall hold harmless the city and the city council, its officers, employees, and agents, from liability for damages arising from any act or omission emanating from an event. The sponsor of such event, including the individual named on the application, shall be responsible for any damage caused to the person or property of anyone during the occurrence of such event. The sponsor may have insurance to cover the sponsor's liability herein, and if so, a copy of such insurance shall name the city as a loss payee; and a copy of such policy shall be presented to the clerk prior to the event occurring. It shall be the responsibility of the sponsor to collect 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 152/321 damages from any person or entity that causes the damage if the sponsor wishes to be reimbursed for any damages caused to it that are required to be paid to the city. (Ord. No. 2009-01, § 8, 8-3-2009) Sec. 26-26. - Alcoholic beverages. No alcoholic beverages may be consumed during an event in the city. (Ord. No. 2009-01, § 9, 8-3-2009) Sec. 26-27. - Obscene or vulgar materials or language. No obscene or vulgar materials or language are permitted at an event; and the occurrence of such that is not immediately abated upon request by an employee, mayor, or councilmember may result in the immediate termination of such event. (Ord. No. 2009-01, § 10, 8-3-2009) Sec. 26-28. - Noise. The noise level at an event shall not be so loud that it disturbs the neighbors. A complaint by one or more occupants of a residence located nearby shall result in an investigation; and if in the opinion of the mayor or the mayor's designee the noise level remains at such a high level to annoy or disturb neighbors, then the event may be immediately terminated. Should the city adopt a noise ordinance at a later date, then the noise ordinance shall automatically apply to any event that occurs within the city. (Ord. No. 2009-01, § 11, 8-3-2009) Sec. 26-29. - Exemptions. The following are exempted from and do not have to comply with the terms of this article: (1) Any event sponsored by the city. (2) Any church that holds an event and is totally confined to its own property. (3) Any family event limited primarily to family members held on private property. (4) Any sporting events that occur on private property and in which vendors are not utilized. (5) Pickup games or sports events that are not present or exempt provided that the participants clean up after themselves. (Ord. No. 2009-01, § 12, 8-3-2009) Sec. 26-30. - Streets. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 153/321 In no event may any street be blocked by an event without the acceptance and prior written permission of the city even if such event is an event exempted as stated in section 26-29. (Ord. No. 2009-01, § 13, 8-3-2009) Sec. 26-31. - Trash facilities. The sponsor of an event shall be required to provide temporary garbage and recycling collection facilities at any event at which existing permanent collection facilities are determined by the city to be inadequate. The sponsor shall be required to submit a refundable deposit of $50.00 with the city to ensure facilities and grounds are adequately cleaned. Such deposit will be refunded as long as the sponsor cleans up the area involved and otherwise complied with the requirements of this article. (Ord. No. 2009-01, § 14, 8-3-2009) Sec. 26-32. - Cessation of activities. The safety, health, welfare, and good order of all citizens and the community shall be first and foremost and every event shall be conducted in such manner. The mayor or his designee may terminate any activity, whether a part of or the entire event, which does not meet this community standard. Upon notification of the event sponsor in person or any other person in charge at the time by the mayor or his designee to cease any activity, it shall be unlawful for such sponsor and/or participants to permit such activity to continue. (Ord. No. 2009-01, § 15, 8-3-2009) Sec. 26-33. - Additional requirements. The city council shall from time to time have the right to make such additional requirements as necessary without amending this article by placing the same on the application. (Ord. No. 2009-01, § 16, 8-3-2009) Sec. 26-34. - Penalties. Every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this article shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 per occurrence or by an imprisonment of not more than 90 days, or both by such fine and imprisonment. (Ord. No. 2009-01, § 17, 8-3-2009)

div.head: Chapter 28 - SUBDIVISIONS
div.p: ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 28-1. - Short title. These regulations shall be known as the "Land Subdivision Ordinance." (Ord. No. 2000-2, § 1-1, 6-5-2000) Sec. 28-2. - Purpose. This article is enacted pursuant to the authority contained in the state constitution, as amended, for the following purposes: (1) To encourage economically sound and stable land development. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 154/321 (2) To ensure the provision of required streets, utilities, and other facilities and services to land developments. (3) To ensure the adequate provision of safe and convenient traffic access and circulation, both vehicular and pedestrian, in land developments. (4) To ensure the provision of needed public open spaces and building sites in land developments through the dedication or reservation of land for recreational, educational and other public purposes. (5) To ensure that land is developed in conformity with the 2010 Greater Tift County Comprehensive Plan. (Ord. No. 2000-2, § 1-2, 6-5-2000) Sec. 28-3. - Jurisdiction. This article shall govern the subdivision of land within the incorporated area of the city. (Ord. No. 2000-2, § 1-3, 6-5-2000) Sec. 28-4. - Definitions. The mayor and council's interpretation shall be final as to the meaning of any definition, statement, requirement, symbol, and/or abbreviation used in connection with these regulations and/or their application. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Abutting property means any property that is immediately adjacent or contiguous to property proposed to be subdivided or that is located immediately across any road or public right-of-way. Alleys means a public right-of-way not intended to be a vehicular arterial or to provide the primary means of access to abutting property, but used for service access to the rear or side properties otherwise abutting a public street. Applicant means any person who submits subdivision plans to the city for the purpose of obtaining approval thereof. Architect means a qualified person registered and currently licensed or otherwise authorized to practice architecture in the state. Building line means a line beyond which no foundation wall or part of the structure of any building shall project, with the exception of roof overhang, walkways, and the subsurface projection of footings; provided, however, that such overhang does not exceed six feet and does not encroach upon the adjacent property or right-of-way. Chairperson means the chairperson of the planning and zoning commission. City engineer means a public official appointed by the mayor who has specialized training in engineering and state certification. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 155/321 Comprehensive plan means the 2010 Greater Tift County Comprehensive Plan, as duly amended, reviewed by the planning commission and/or the mayor and council, which may consist of the major thoroughfare plan, general land use plan, street and road classification plan, and other maps, data, and descriptive matter for the physical development of the city or any portions thereof, including any amendments, extensions, or additions thereto as adopted by the planning commission and/or the mayor and council. Consultant means the licensed design or engineering professional or firm hired by the subdivider to oversee all aspects of the subdivision and design process. Crosswalk means a right-of-way within a block dedicated to public use for pedestrian use only and so designed as to provide access to adjacent streets or lots. Cul-de-sac means a street having only one end open for access to another street, the other end being terminated by a turnaround as specified in this chapter. Developer means the same as subdivider. Development means the act or process of erecting buildings or structures, or of making improvements to property, or of laying out and dividing land. Easement means a grant by the owner of land for the use of such land by others, including public usage, for a specific purpose. Exempt subdivision means any subdivision that has approved zoning and has had a plat submitted for approval by the city engineer, the planning and zoning commission and the mayor and council prior to the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, shall be declared an exempt subdivision, and acted upon under the conditions of the ordinances that were in place at the time such plat was submitted. Floodprone area means an area identified as having a potential flood hazard pursuant to chapter 16, Floods. Guarantee means a maintenance bond in the amount of 15 percent, required by this chapter, which guarantees to the city all materials and workmanship of any minimum improvements installed in a subdivision. Hardship means a situation arising as the result of extraneous or unique circumstances which deprives the developer of the reasonable use of his land if the strict application of the various provisions of this chapter are applied. (See Variance.) Improvement plan means the second stage of plat or subdivision plan review, as described in section 28-80. For the purpose of the enforcement of this chapter, the improvement plan must include the soil erosion and sedimentation control plan and land disturbance permit application. Landscape architect means a design professional registered and currently licensed or otherwise authorized to practice landscape architecture in the state, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 43-23-1, providing the services therein defined. Lot means a parcel of land separated from other parcels by description as shown on a subdivision plat, a survey map recorded in the county superior court clerk's office, or as described by a metes and bounds description found in a deed of record recorded in said clerk's office and which parcel is intended for transfer of ownership or for building development. For the purpose of this chapter, the term "lot" does not include any portion of a dedicated right-of-way. Lot, corner, means a parcel of land at the junction of and fronting on two or more streets. Lot of record means a lot which is part of a subdivision as shown on a plat recorded in the clerk's office of the county superior court, or a parcel described by metes and bounds in the description portion of a deed which has been recorded in said clerk's office prior to July 6, 1999. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 156/321 Lot width means the distance measured straight between the side lot lines, measured at the intersection of the building line, which shall be paralleled to the street right-of-way line. MSL means mean sea level. Parcel means a separate part or portion of land which exists separate and distinct from any other part or parcel. A lot is a parcel, but not all parcels are considered lots. Performance bond means a legal instrument made payable to the city, which a developer may post with the city to permit recording of a final plat prior to completion of the required minimum improvements. Planning commission means the Greater Tift County Planning and Zoning Commission. Plat means a map, generally of a subdivision, showing the location, boundaries and ownership of individual properties. There are two types: (1) Preliminary plat. The first stage of a plat or subdivision plan review, as described in section 28-79 (2) Final plat. The final stage of a plat or subdivision plan review, as described in section 28-81 Private right-of-way means a portion of land being used or to be used as a street, road, thoroughfare, crosswalk, pipeway, drainage canal, and/or other similar uses and designated by means of right-of-way but not deeded to the governing authority. Protective covenant means a private contract existing between the land subdivider or developer and subsequent property owners of a particular defined area, limiting design and usage of similarly situated properties. These instruments are generally publically recorded with a particular land subdivision, and maintenance and enforcement of the contract is between the private parties. Public right-of-way means a portion of land being used or to be used as a public street, road, thoroughfare, crosswalk, pipeway, drainage canal, and/or other similar uses and designated by means of right-of-way deed to the governing authority. Public water and sewer system means a system owned and operated by the city or county. Secretary means the respective secretaries of the planning and zoning commission, as duly appointed by their respective local governments. Staff development review committee means a committee of public employees with specific technical expertise who are officially responsible to the mayor and council for various public management functions. Under this chapter, the staff development review committee shall assist the planning commission and mayor and council in the review of the numerous technical functions associated with the land subdivision process. This committee shall be appointed by the mayor and council. Streets and/or roads means a way or thoroughfare which can be and is generally used for travel, but does not include service entrances or driveways leading off or from a street onto adjoining property. (1) Streets and/or roads may be designated as public or private, which shall be defined as follows: a. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 157/321 Public street and/or road. When the county, city, state, or federal government owns the right of way and is responsible for maintenance. b. Private street or road. When the right of way is owned by someone or some entity other than the county, city, state, or federal government. (2) Streets and/or roads throughout the city shall further be subdivided and defined as follows: a. Arterial street. A street which is designated as such on the major thoroughfare plan and which is intended to provide swift and safe movement of traffic through the city. b. Collector street. A street which is designated as such on the major thoroughfare plan and which is intended to collect traffic from local streets and direct it safely to arterial streets. c. Dead-end street. A street having only one end open for access to another street, and the other end being abruptly terminated with no turnaround. d. Marginal access street. A street generally parallel to and adjacent to an arterial street providing access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. e. Local street. A street used for local circulation in areas providing access to abutting property. Subdivider means any person or agent who undertakes or proposes to undertake the subdivision of land so as to constitute a subdivision as herein defined. Subdivider's engineer/surveyor means any professional engineer or land surveyor as defined in O.C.G.A. § 43- 15-2, providing the services therein defined. Subdivision means all divisions of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, tracts, parcels, building sites, or other divisions for the purpose, whether immediate or future, for sale, legacy, or building development, including all division of land involving a new street or a change of width or alignment in existing streets, and including resubdivision and, where appropriate to the context, relating to the process of subdividing or to the land or area subdivided; provided, however, that the following are not included within this definition: (1) Where located on an existing public road or street, the combination or recombination of previously platted lots, where the total number of lots is not increased, and the resultant lots are equal to the current standards of the city. (2) The public acquisition of land. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 158/321 (3) The sale of public land. (4) The subdivision of land into parcels of ten acres or more where located on an existing public (city maintained) road. Each ten-acre or larger parcel must abut a public road a minimum of 80 feet. (5) A division or sale of land among heirs by judicial decree, provided that all lots created by the subdivision must front existing state or, city roads or an approved private road, and lot size, frontage, and access requirements dictated in the zoning ordinance have been met. Subdivision plans are interpreted to be all plans required for delineation of rights-of-way, easements, lots, preservation areas, etc., and all construction plans required for the development of all physical facilities pertaining thereto. Tax assessor means the Tift County Board of Tax Assessors. Tift County Health Department means the Tift County Board of Health, the Tift County Health Department and/or the State of Georgia Department of Human Resources. The terms "Tift County Health Department" and/or "Tift County Environmental Officer" are used in this chapter to denote the fact that all matters pertaining to health regulations shall be directed to that official or his staff. Tract means a portion of land with definite and ascertainable limits or boundaries. Utility means any community service available to the public by means of an overhead or underground distribution or collection system such as electricity, telecommunications, water, gas, and sewage disposal. Variance means the relaxation of a dimensional requirement or design standard described within this chapter as it applies to the development of a particular tract or parcel of land reviewed by the planning and zoning commission and approved by the mayor and council on an individual basis, after proper public hearing. Zoning administrator means the person appointed by the mayor and council to coordinate among various agencies involved in review and approval of subdivision plans and ensuring compliance of subdividers to administrative requirements of this chapter. Zoning ordinance means the zoning ordinance enacted by the mayor and council as duly amended. (Ord. No. 2000-2, § 2-1, 6-5-2000) Sec. 28-5. - Violations. (a) It shall be unlawful to convey or improve property by the construction of buildings on lots of any land subdivision which has not been approved and recorded as provided in this chapter, except those parcels recorded prior to the effective date of the city zoning ordinance. (b) It shall be unlawful to record a subdivision plat which has not been approved by the planning and zoning commission and signed by the chairperson of that commission. It shall be unlawful to alter recorded subdivision 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 159/321 plats without prior approval of the planning commission, unless the purpose of such alteration is to combine or increase the size of existing lots. (Ord. No. 2000-2, § 8-1, 6-5-2000) Secs. 28-6—28-35. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION Sec. 28-36. - Platting authority. From and after the passage of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, the planning commission shall be the official platting authority, and no plat of a land subdivision shall be recorded in the clerk's office of the county superior court unless it has the approval of the planning commission inscribed thereon. The filing or recording of a plat of a subdivision without the approval of the appropriate reviewing agencies and/or authorities as required by this section is declared to be a violation of this section. (Ord. No. 2000-2, § 3-1, 6-5-2000) Sec. 28-37. - Use of plat. The transfer of, sale of, agreement to sell, or negotiation to sell land by reference to, exhibition of, or other use of a plat of a subdivision that has not been given final approval by the planning commission and recorded in the clerk's office of the county superior court is prohibited, and the description by metes and bounds in such an instrument of transfer or other document shall not exempt the transaction from prescribed penalties. (Ord. No. 2000-2, § 3-2, 6-5-2000) Sec. 28-38. - Opening and improving public streets. The mayor and council shall not accept, lay out, open, improve, grade, pave, or light any street, or lay any utility lines in any street, which has not attained the status of a public street prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, unless such street corresponds to the street location shown on an approved subdivision plat or the major thoroughfare plan; provided that the mayor and council may accept, lay out, open, and improve any street not so platted if it first submits such proposed action to the planning commission for its review and comment and approves the same as an amendment to the major thoroughfare plan. Developers of subdivisions will be solely responsible for acquiring all rights-of-way so that in the event that the city needs to perform maintenance, rights-of-way will be in place. (Ord. No. 2000-2, § 3-3, 6-5-2000) Sec. 28-39. - Issuance of building permits. Building permits will not be issued for a lot or building site subject to this chapter that has not been designated and recorded as required by this chapter. Lots of record are not subject to this requirement per section 28-42. (Ord. No. 2000-2, § 3-4, 6-5-2000) Sec. 28-40. - Compliance with zoning ordinance required. No final plat of a subdivision shall be accepted for review which does not conform with the city zoning ordinance. Proposed subdivisions must conform with the zoning district classification requirements applicable to the land for which they are proposed. (Ord. No. 2000-2, § 3-5, 6-5-2000) Sec. 28-41. - Official interpretation. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 160/321 The requirements of this chapter, as they may apply to a proposed land subdivision, shall be officially interpreted by the staff development review committee. In cases which the subdivider disagrees with the official interpretation of these regulations, the developer may appeal to the planning commission and the mayor and city council pursuant to the guidelines established in section 28-44. (Ord. No. 2000-2, § 3-6, 6-5-2000) Sec. 28-42. - Nonconforming lots. Any lot for which a plat or legal description (i.e., metes and bounds) has been recorded in the clerk's office of the county superior court, which was recorded prior to the adoption of the city's zoning ordinance, shall be recognized as a nonconforming lot of record and may be utilized for any of the uses permitted by the city zoning ordinance in its respective zoning district, subject to current zoning ordinance limitations. (Ord. No. 2000-2, § 3-7, 6-5-2000) Sec. 28-43. - Variances. All variances shall be recommended by the planning commission on a case-by-case basis. Any request for variance shall be based on circumstances unique to the subject property, and proposed alternate design or improvements must follow accepted engineering practices and principles. Final decisions on variances are made by the mayor and council pursuant to section 28-44. (Ord. No. 2000-2, § 3-8, 6-5-2000) Sec. 28-44. - Petitions for variances; public hearings. In cases of undue hardship under this chapter, or on questions of official interpretation per section 28-41, any property owner may petition the planning commission for a variance, and where the planning commission concurs, it will prepare and send to the mayor and council a recommendation for a variance when considered necessary and equitable. In case the planning commission fails to concur, the property owner may appeal to the mayor and council for relief. All variance requests will require a public hearing in the same manner as an amendment to the city's zoning ordinance. None of the items listed in article V of this chapter shall be subject to variance. (Ord. No. 2000-2, § 9-4, 6-5-2000) Sec. 28-45. - Amendments. The ordinance from which this chapter is derived may be amended from time to time by the mayor and city council, and all amendments shall be submitted to the planning commission for its review and recommendation. Prior to enacting an amendment to the ordinance, the city shall hold a public hearing thereon, and give at least 15 days' but not more than 45 days' notice of the time and place of, which shall be published in the official legal organ of the city. (Ord. No. 2000-2, § 9-3, 6-5-2000) Sec. 28-46. - Appeal—Mayor and council. Any party aggrieved because of alleged error in any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by the zoning administrator, planning commission, or any other party in enforcement of this article, may appeal to the city council by filing, in writing, to the city clerk for an interpretation of the pertinent zoning code provision. The appeals procedure shall be the same as used for appeals from the planning commission to the city council on zoning cases. In exercising this power of interpretation, the mayor and council may, in conformity with the provisions of this article, reverse or affirm any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by the zoning administrator, planning commission, or any other party pursuant to section 28-44. 8/30/2019 Ty Ty, GA Code of Ordinances 161/321 (Ord. No. 2000-2, § 3-9, 6-5-2000) Sec. 28-47. - Same—Court of record.
